citation.article-title: Methylocystis heyeri sp. nov., a novel type II methanotrophic bacterium possessing 'signature' fatty acids of type I methanotrophs.
citation.source: International Journal of Systematic and Evolutionary Microbiology

p.s: Description of Methylocystis heyeri sp. nov.

Methylocystis heyeri (hey.e′ri. N.L. gen. n. heyeri of Heyer, named in honour of the German microbiologist Jürgen Heyer, for his highly enthusiastic research on methanotrophic bacteria and his contributions to increasing our knowledge on methanotroph diversity and ecology).
Cells are large, straight or regularly curved rods or ovoids; 0.8–1.2 μm wide and 1.4–4.0 μm long.
Old cultures may contain misshapen and forked cells or nearly closed crescents.
Cells possess large capsules so that each cell is separated from the others by plenty of the capsular material.
Colonies are white, highly raised and slimy.
Grows at temperatures between 5 and 30 °C (optimum at 25 °C) and at pH values between 4.4 and 7.5 (optimum at 5.8–6.2).
Carbon sources include methane and methanol.
Methanol is utilized at concentrations below 1 % (v/v); optimal growth occurs at 0.1 % (v/v) methanol.
NaCl inhibits growth at concentrations above 0.5 %.
The type strain, H2T (=DSM 16984T=VKM B-2426T), was isolated from the acidic Sphagnum peat bog lake Teufelssee, north-eastern Germany.
Strain Sakb1 is a reference strain, isolated from acidic tropical forest soil (Thailand).
The DNA G+C contents of strains H2T and Sakb1 are 61.5 and 62.1 mol%, respectively.
